transcript:
Therapist: Let's start by discussing relapse prevention and how you can maintain the progress you've made after our sessions end. One important aspect of relapse prevention is identifying early warning signs that your depression may be worsening. What do you think some of your early warning signs might be?

Patient: I think one warning sign for me is when I start isolating myself more and not reaching out to friends or family. Another sign is when I have trouble getting out of bed in the morning and just feel really exhausted all the time.

Therapist: Those are great insights. Isolating yourself and experiencing increased fatigue can definitely be early warning signs of depression. What are some other signs you've noticed in the past?

Patient: I guess another sign is when I start having more negative thoughts about myself and my future. Like, I'll start thinking that I'm never going to get better or that I'm a burden on others.

Therapist: That's a really important sign to be aware of. Noticing an increase in negative thoughts can help you catch depression early and take steps to manage it. What do you think you could do if you notice these warning signs?

Patient: I think I could try to reach out to someone I trust, like a friend or my sister, and let them know I'm struggling. I could also try to do some of the coping strategies we've talked about, like thought records or behavioral activation.

Therapist: Those are great ideas. Reaching out for support and using your coping strategies can be really helpful in managing depression. Another important part of relapse prevention is having a plan in place for how you'll support yourself after therapy ends. What are some ways you can continue to support yourself and maintain your progress?

Patient: I think it'll be important for me to keep practicing the skills we've worked on, even when I'm feeling better. I can keep doing thought records and trying to challenge my negative thoughts. I can also try to stay connected with my support system and reach out when I need help.

Therapist: Absolutely. Continuing to practice your skills and staying connected with your support system are key parts of maintaining your progress. It can also be helpful to have a list of resources you can turn to if you need additional support, like a therapist you can see for booster sessions or a support group for people with depression.

Patient: That's a good idea. I know there are some support groups in my area, so I could look into those. And it's good to know that I can come back for booster sessions if I need to.

Therapist: Definitely. Having those resources in place can give you a sense of security and help you feel more confident in your ability to manage your depression going forward. Remember, you've made incredible progress in our work together, and you have the skills and tools you need to continue that progress on your own.

Patient: Thanks, that means a lot to hear you say that. I know I've come a long way, and I feel more prepared to handle things now.

Therapist: You absolutely have. I have complete confidence in your ability to continue using your skills and maintaining your progress. And remember, if you ever need additional support, you can always reach out. You don't have to do this alone.

Patient: Thanks, I appreciate that. It's good to know I have options if I need them.

Therapist: You're welcome. Before we move on, let's create a written relapse prevention plan that outlines your early warning signs, coping strategies, and resources for support. That way, you'll have a concrete plan to refer to if you need it.

Patient: That's a great idea. Let's do that.

Therapist: Great. Why don't you start by listing your early warning signs, and then we can brainstorm coping strategies for each one?

Patient: Okay, so for isolating myself, I could reach out to a friend or family member and make plans to do something together. For fatigue, I could try to stick to a regular sleep schedule and do some light exercise, like going for a walk.

Therapist: Those are great strategies. What about for increased negative thoughts?

Patient: For negative thoughts, I could do a thought record to challenge them and try to come up with more balanced thoughts. I could also read through my coping cards to remind myself of my new core beliefs.

Therapist: Excellent. Those are really effective strategies for managing negative thoughts. Let's write all of this down in your relapse prevention plan, along with your resources for support.
